prompt: Facts: The appellant, Ratilal Bhanji Muthani, was apprehended by Customs Officers near Bassein Creek.; Upon searching the appellant, a specially tailored jacket containing 25 slabs of gold was found concealed underneath his regular clothes.; The gold weighed approximately 2497.900 grams.; The gold was seized under a panchnama.; The appellant was charged with offences under the Defence of India Rules, 1971 (DIR) and the Customs Act, 1962.; Specifically, charges were framed under Rule 126-H(2)(d) read with Rule 126-P(2)(ii) of the DIR and Section 135(1)(a) of the Customs Act, 1962.; The Trial Court convicted the appellant under both statutory provisions.; The High Court of Bombay upheld the conviction on appeal.; The appellant subsequently appealed to the Supreme Court, primarily challenging the conviction on the ground that the prosecution failed to prove 'mens rea' (guilty knowledge) beyond reasonable doubt.; The core factual element relied upon by the prosecution was the discovery of gold concealed on the appellant's person in a specially made jacket. | IPC: Note: This case primarily involves offences under the Customs Act, 1962 and the Defence of India Rules, 1971, not the Indian Penal Code (IPC). The relevant penal sections from those acts are listed below. However, the judgment extensively discusses the principle of 'mens rea', a fundamental concept in criminal law applicable across statutes, including the IPC., Customs Act, 1962: Section 135(1)(a), Defence of India Rules, 1971: Rule 126-H(2)(d) read with Rule 126-P(2)(ii)
